explanation:
For checking MISRA C 'no language extensions' in this function you must inspect any macros, typedefs, structure definitions and global objects referenced by the function because extensions typically appear there (e.g. GCC statement-expressions, typeof, __attribute__, inline-asm, builtins, etc.). Explainations for each symbol:
- OS_CHECK_POINTER: This is a macro used at the top of the function. Macros are a common place for compiler extensions (statement-expressions, __builtin_expect, attributes, etc.), so its definition must be examined.
- OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET: This macro is used to access the object table entry. Its implementation could use extensions (typeof, statement-expr, compound literals, unusual indexing), so the macro body is needed.
- OS_stream_internal_record_t: The structure type of 'stream' — its definition may contain bit-fields, compiler-specific attributes, or anonymous unions/structs (which can be language extensions depending on compiler), so inspect the type.
- OS_stream_table: The global table object referenced by the macro may be defined with nonstandard storage-class specifiers or attributes (section placement, packed, aligned), so its declaration/definition is required.
- OS_object_iter_t: The iterator type; its layout or helper macros could use extensions (anonymous struct/union, flexible array members in a nonstandard way), so include its definition.
- int32: The typedef underlying int32 may be a compiler-specific typedef or macro (e.g. using __attribute__ or nonstandard integer types); check its definition to ensure it is standard C compliant.
- OS_FS_ERR_PATH_INVALID: The symbolic constant assigned to return_code — check how it is defined (macro, enum, or expression) for use of extensions.
- OS_SocketDomain_INVALID: Enum/constant used in the comparison; its definition may use compiler extensions (attributes, unusual enum size directives) and must be checked.
- OS_ObjectIdIterateActive: Function/macro that initializes the iterator. If it is a macro it may use extensions; its prototype/definition is needed to ensure no extensions affect correctness.
- OS_ObjectIdIteratorGetNext: Called in the loop condition; if it is a macro or inline function it could use extensions — include its definition.
- OS_ObjectIdIteratorProcessEntry: Called to process/close the entry; include its declaration/definition because it may be a macro that uses extensions or a function taking function-pointer types with nonstandard attributes.
- OS_FileIteratorClose: The callback passed into the iterator process function; its prototype/type must be inspected for any extension usage (attributes, calling convention, varargs, etc.).
- OS_ObjectIdIteratorDestroy: Called at end; include its definition in case it is implemented with macros or uses extensions.
- OS_ObjectIndexFromToken: This symbol is commonly used by object-table macros (and appears in the call graph). The macro OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET or related helper may expand to call it or depend on its prototype; include to inspect for extension usage.
- strcmp: Although a standard library function, including its declaration (string.h) confirms standard usage; sometimes projects replace or wrap it with nonstandard variants or macros.

Providing these definitions allows examining whether any of the above introduce compiler/language extensions in the code paths used by OS_CloseFileByName. Only by inspecting the macro and type definitions can one determine if the function text itself relies on nonstandard language features that violate the MISRA rule.
